commitResults.messageTitle: Rename main class to 'HypeBot'
commitResults.messageBody:
Main class name is the default 'Duke'.

The lack of a distinct identity between this new chatbot
and the original Duke makes it hard to differentiate
between the two.

Giving this chatbot a distinct identity allows us to
have an emotional attachment and dedication to
producing a higher quality product. It also allows
users to form an emotional attachment to the
chatbot so they can enjoy spending time interacting
with it.

Let's rename this chatbot 'HypeBot'.

Renaming this chatbot to reflect its desired personality
of a cheerful, motivating companion sets users'
expectations on how their interactions with the chatbot
are going to feel.

commitResults.messageTitle: README: Update name in title from 'Duke' to 'HypeBot'
Add greeting and exit methods
commitResults.messageBody:
There is only a greeting that is triggered in the
main() method.

The lack of an exit and the lack of separation
between a greeting and an exit complicate the
start and end of the conversation between the
user and the bot.

Extracting the greeting and exit behaviour
each allows us to control the interface at the
start and end of the conversation between the
user and the bot.

Let's make a greet() method that welcomes the
user and and exit() method that wishes them
goodbye.

Separating the greeting and exit message ensures
they can be called separately.

commitResults.messageTitle: Reformat logo and greeting
commitResults.messageBody:
Logo is multiple concatenated strings,
while greeting does not directly prompt
user for a command.

Not being able to visualise the logo
as a single string block makes adjusting
mistakes in ASCII art difficult, while
not directly prompting user for a command
could confuse user and prevent them
from initiating interaction with HypeBot.

Let's convert the logo into a single
string block using \s and prompt the user
for a command.

Refer to Ghost font provided by
https://www.asciiart.eu/text-to-ascii-art

commitResults.messageTitle: Add support for echo
commitResults.messageBody:
HypeBot has no support for accepting user
input or reacting to it.

HypeBot needs to be able to accept user
input and have some kind of input handling
so that when the user types in some form of
exit command, HypeBot is able to act accordingly
by calling the exit() method.

Let's use a Scanner and a while loop that
constantly checks whether the exit
command 'bye' in any form of
capitalisation to exit, otherwise
repeat the user's input allows us to
achieve basic echo functionality.

Using a temporary boolean variable as
the condition for the input loop
allows us to store the command entered,
process it into lowercase so we don't
have to test for all combinations which
the command 'bye' can be entered.

Add Task class with name and completion status
Extracted add(), list() methods and added mark(), unmark() methods
Add ToDo.java which inherits Task.java
Add Deadline.java which inherits Task.java, has a new attribute dueDate
Add Event.java which inherits from Task.java, has additional startTime and endTime
Change add message to show number of tasks user has
Reformat Task.toString() so there is no newline at the end
Add support for different types of Tasks (ToDos, Deadlines, Events)
commitResults.messageBody:
Refactor adding buffer lines to their own
methods

Reformat input handling into switch-case
statement with more comprehensive error
handling

commitResults.messageBody:
The Parser currently handles all user input and error handling for user
input. This is violation of SLAP.

Separating Parsers for different types of parsing helps reinforce OOP
principles and keep better track of error handling across different
across different errors encountered.

Let's extract a CommandParser to make sense of which Commands to be
executed by the system, a DateTimeParser to parse dates and times,
an IndexParser to make sense of indexes entered, and a TaskParser to
make sense of information entered into Task objects.

Following SLAP is important for code readability, quality, and ease for
debugging when encountering unexpected errors.
